review.title: Intelligent decision: towards interpreting the Pe Algorithm
review.abstract: The human intelligence lies in the algorithm, the nature of algorithms lies in the classification, and the classification is equal to outlier detection. This paper is based on its past unpublished edition (2009), which discussed an application of (pe) algorithm in outlier detection for time series data. The pe algorithm, also named as RDD algorithm, is originated from the study on general AI. United with it, designed modules can be used to realize kinds of tasks. A primary framework concerned with the mind through pe algorithm has been constructed in prior works. In this concise paper, we neglect background and minor description of the early edition, and directly discuss the main contents include longest k-turn subsequence problem, curve type outliers, futural directions and related comments.

metadata.title: פ Algorithm: its past present, futue present and comments

sections.text: Human intelligence is in the algorithm, the nature of the algorithms is in the classification, and classification is synonymous with outlier detection. This paper is based on its last unpublished edition (2009), which discussed the application of the "pe" algorithm to outlier detection of time series data, also known as the "RDD algorithm," derived from the General Artificial Intelligence Study. Combined with it, designed modules can be used to perform types of tasks. In previous work, a primary framework has been developed that deals with the mind through the "algorithm." In this short essay, we neglect the background and minor descriptions of the early edition, and discuss directly the main contents, including longest k-turn sequence problems, outliers of the curve type, future directions and related comments. In the section "Present in the Past," we keep all previous conclusions, although a little may be out of date.

sections.heading: I. Past Present
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1. Relative deviation degree
sections.text: A supplementary definition of outliers (Hsiao et al., 2008) Definition 1: An outlier is an observation with a degree greater than a threshold compared to other observations related to or associated with one or more specified patterns. Problem 1: Given time series data S1 as Figure 1, we assume that the data correspond to a linear model, find out that outliers S1 = (3.1, 2.9, 2.85, 3.05, 2.9, 3.2, 5.4, 5.3, 5.3, 2.99, 3, 3.2, 3.2) Fig.1. Regression lines for dataset S102468100 2 4 6 8, 18 20data LS LTSBy classic LS regression, we get a line y = 3.79-0.0001x; and through robust LTS regression, liney = 2.907 + 0.007 x, as shown in Figure 1.

sections.heading: 2. Longest k –turn subsequence
sections.text: In this section, we present an expression for the "curve" pattern, so that we can get a kind of view of "algorithm." Outlier problem of time series data can be described as follows. Problem 2: In view of a sequence S with the longest length N, {d1, d2,... dN}, which corresponds to pattern curve, you will find outliers. An example is shown in Figure 2. How each curve can be expressed by several ordered sequences passed by several common points (turn points), we develop a dynamic programming algorithm to detect the order of curve type data, which can be traced back to the longest increasing sequence problem (Schensted, 1961). First, we give a definition of "turn" 4: in view of a curve, except for boundary points, each extreme point is referred to as "turn point"; the number of extreme points is referred to as turn points.

sections.heading: 3. Time series data outlier
sections.text: Algorithm 4: Denote point (i, di) by pi, i = 0, 1,..., N-1 Enter a curve pattern [character, T]: a curve with [character, T] passing pi, Denote similarity function by, Offset function by, Offset function by k = 0, 1,..., N-1Input: Time series data S Output: RDDs of S1. For each Pi calculate a sub sequence P (S) i with T turns and maximum length by algorithm 3. 2. In Fig. 3, Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, it is an obvious problem. One is an effective pattern of CO2 flow, one is sensitive heat flow data, and the other is latent heat flow data. Both are obtained from the Yucheng Station, China. However, in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, apparent outliers (19, 34, 35, 36, 43, 44 in Fig. 3 and 9,12,24,25 in Fig. 4) do not appear to be detected, although their RDD values are closest to the determined outlier values (19 in Table 2 and 12 in Table 3). Has the algorithm failed? In fact, one would rather say that the two points associated with the "pattern" do not appear as prominent as we erroneously did not recognize them. And from the following examples, we will see that our algorithm can work even in some hard cases.

sections.heading: II. Futural Present
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1. A new example
sections.text: The research was stopped in 2009 for some special reasons. It is stimulated by a student in St. Louis. Here is a new example (Fig. 8), and the same algorithm is used. We give a detailed analysis to supplement past conclusions. However, before we give the result, we can imagine our own answer. The disturbed points in our minds (natural principle) could be the fourth, 15th, 16th, 18th, 22nd, 24th, 27th and 36th. If we remove these points, we can have a clean row like Fig. 9. One can have his own answer, based on his best principle. Now, we want to see what the entire algorithm tells us. Table 4 lists all outliers with appropriate RDD values. When the clean data are removed, the clean data will show up as Fig.10.Fig.8. St. Louis data-3000-2500-2000-1000-5000150020000.

sections.heading: 2. Future work
sections.text: And if angular consistency is taken into account, only the 24th date would be an outlier. In order to achieve a consistent result with the human mind, we could magnify the necessary views. Once we are inserted into a complete set, we get a complete knowledge. Other immediate applications of this algorithm are in the areas of image processing, pattern recognition, etc.

sections.heading: III. Comments
sections.text: We must understand that there is no "objective" outlier. If objectivity is expressed as the main stream, we recognize that this kind of objectivity is a reasonable description. The Supreme Court has the power of definitive interpretation, justice is appointed by the president, the president is chosen by all, and all are necessary to be honest. That's a kind of order, and that's what the algorithm tells us. What inner order we have, what outer order we achieve. That's also what Godel's theorems show us.
